Shanu is a Portfolio Manager/Analyst for Lazard’s $500M US Sustainable Equity mutual fund and also leads up Decarbonization & Net Zero research for the US Equity platform (~$40BN AUM) at Lazard Asset Management ($225BN+ AUM). Shanu spends time conducting research on new and existing stock ideas that may see sustainability-focused tailwinds, analyzing corporate climate ambitions, and helping out with our environmental-focused engagements with companies held in portfolios. He began working in the investment field in 2015. Prior to joining Lazard in 2021, Shanu was a Vice President and Head of ESG at First Eagle Alternative Credit, a $20 billion+ alternative asset manager. Shanu is also a member of the Investment Committee at Evergreen Climate Innovations, a recurring guest on Wood Mackenzie’s ‘The Energy Gang’ podcast, and has spoken at climate-related industry events including for the CFA Society of New York and The Summit for Asset Management, among other involvement across the climate ecosystem. He has a Bachelor of Science dual-degree in Accounting and Finance from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

A Petroleum Engineer passionate about energy, economy, and politics with Brazilian and Italian citizenship.   Currently, at Harbour Energy plc, I work for the International team as a Planning & Economics Adviser and act as the STEM Ambassador London Chair coordinating activities that promote the importance of STEM and Energy for our lives in schools around London.  In these 7 years working in different companies, I believe that among my main characteristics stand out: ★ Multidisciplinary - I try to know a little of everything within the organizations I work with. ★ Organised - I prefer to plan, assess risks and define responsibilities beforehand. ★ Curious - the key to learning faster is recognising that you do not know and ask. ★ Cooperative - the easiest way to know other areas is by helping colleagues. ★ Dedicated - when you love what you do, dedication makes you enjoy the journey.  Having lived in 3 different countries (Brazil, Colombia, and the UK) and working directly with other diverse cultures, I consider myself adaptable, flexible and a team player.  As an engineer, I have worked for several technical functions, both onshore and offshore. Also, I have strong experience with software and processes in areas such as project planning, economics modeling, budgeting, financial modeling, portfolio maturation, 2P reserves and 2C resource booking following the SPE PRMS, reservoir simulation, well planning, risk assessment and management, incident reporting, multiphase flow simulator, and well integrity, among others. I am also experienced with both PSC Cost Recovery, PSC Gross Split and Royalty based contracts.  Concerned with issues related to the low employability of young professionals in Brazil and subjects such as security, accessibility and environmental impacts within the energy transition, in 2020 I co-founded and led for 2 years the Until the Last Barrel (Até o Último Barril), a voluntary organisation formed by professionals that seeks to place young people as a protagonist of these discussions.  Personally speaking, I am outgoing, I drink a lot of mate (traditional South-American tea), play accordion and I am always practicing some physical activity.

As an entrepreneur with more than 25 years of experience and leadership in technology, I am passionate about creating cloud-computing software solutions for business problems primarily found within the energy industry. I have dedicated my career to software engineering and building companies that develop, market, implement and support those systems for enterprise customers.  My approach as a technology leader is very "hands-on" regarding architecture and product design.  I started LiquidFrameworks in 2005 and grew the business from bootstrap to venture to private equity and ultimately sold it to a strategic software company in 2021. LiquidFrameworks is an OEM Salesforce partner that provides the FieldFX product suite, a field operations management solution specifically designed for service providers in the upstream oilfield, industrial service and emergency response industries.  FieldFX is a cloud-based software package delivered on the Salesforce Platform to companies that have a mobile workforce operating in disconnected environments.  FieldFX includes modules for E-ticketing, Schedule & Dispatch, Enterprise Asset Management, Timecards, CPQ (Configure, Price, Quote), Invoicing and Analytics.

William M. Taggart IV - A professional engineer for over 35 years, has worked on major projects in deepwater oil/gas, shale oil, copper mining, and refineries. His initial 16 years was spent with a consulting engineer firm in New Orleans designing projects for multiple industries. He then worked for Murphy Oil, designing and troubleshooting oil/gas facilities in the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico, Eagleford Shale, Permian Shale, and internationally. He is recognized as a subject matter expert for control systems and process safety systems. The systems that control industrial applications and protect the personnel, equipment, and the environment from those industrial processes. 

Now focused on large scale energy storage as founder and CEO of Cavern Energy Storage which is developing long duration energy storage for the Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi region. I started working in the oilfield in 1994 after discharge from the United States Navy, where I attended Fire Control A-School. The Fire Control rate is somewhat deceptive, and an FC was in charge of the firing solutions for the weapons systems deployed on our vessels, both defensive and offensive. I began roughnecking for H&P in the Austin Chalk; then I went to work for Nabors around College Station, where a high school friend was living and working for Power Chokes. On my days off, I would ride with him, installing and working on chokes. One day, he suggested that I put my Navy electronics training to work by applying to work with MD/Totco (Varco). So I did and was hired as a field technician... That was a Baptism by fire. I was young; most co-workers were in their mid-thirties or early forties, and I was eager to prove my worth. That was my introduction to the OFS, where the allure of a company truck, fuel card, and cell phone trumped the long hours, days without sleep, and countless nights offshore, the backseat of the truck, or, if you were lucky, a hotel room. I mostly worked offshore and in East Texas before deciding to take a steady area in the Rio Grande Valley. That was my introduction to true South Texas. There, I stayed until Anadrill hired me as an MWD/Directional Driller trainee. Let me tell you, that job could have set with me better. In that tiny little MWD trailer, it sucked, but up on the floor shadowing the Directional Driller and learning his trade was pretty cool. But, the weeks stuck on the rig wore on me, and it was time to twist off and try another calling. This time, it was Cudd Pressure Control.
I tried to get in on Coil tubing because I had a friend who was a supervisor, but in 1998, there needed to be more work with oil, ~$10/bbl. I had to take what was available, and that was in the snubbing department. After six months of sliding pay from shop to field and one job where we never received our Hazard Pay for H2S, I knew the snubbing life wasn't for me. After all, an FC rate was second only to Nuclear, and I knew I was smarter than that. So, I found myself at Halliburton in the Open Hole Wireline Division. That was a step up from the snubbing department @ Cudd. I had high hopes of making it into their engineering program and putting my mind to work rather than my body. Unfortunately, that's not where Halliburton saw me going. After being a Free-bird in the OFS segment, I could come and go as I pleased, visit with customers when I pleased, and be the on-call fixer; a rigid high school-type environment lost its appeal no matter the benefits involved. I then returned to work in the instrumentation business for Nabors Industries (EPOCH). I was initially hired to fill a void in the International ranks but quickly became a crucial South Texas Operations Division employee. That is where I first learned that being good at your job and always being the person to say yes can harm your career ambitions. After several years of getting the runaround over why I couldn't work internationally and how it would hurt South Texas, I left and found myself interviewing for an Account Managers position for Coastal Chemical Company.
I was always told to get out of the drilling side, where production was steadier, so it seemed like a good move. 2002 Coastal Chemical hired me as an Account Manager for the Western GOM. I thought that sounded cool. I had every standing platform in the Western GOM from Galveston to Brownsville. (Not so cool). But, as a chemical hand in production, you were considered non-essential, so there were very few critical boat rides and if the weather could have been better, I was the first one in and the last one out. It was indeed an excellent job until... I had my first encounter with what chemicals were all about. That is where I cut my teeth; all those years of electronics and instrumentation training kicked in, not to mention the drilling side. It gave me a complete visual of the problem, where it was coming from, and how I needed to identify where to find and apply a solution. After several years with Coastal Offshore and knowing what the Obama Administration had in store for the offshore industry, I transferred to land. 

I was promised that as I grew the land business, I would be promoted out of the field; as that happened, one excuse after another was given, and others were given positions promised to me. At the same time, some veteran offshore guys were jumping ship to Multi-Chem, and most ended up in the Technical Services Department because of their offshore experience and knowledge. Offshore, we have limited space and time to find a solution before the oil and water are sent overboard to discharge or the sales meter. That is when Multi-Chem approached me, and I eventually made the move myself. It was a great experience; I learned, matured, and studied some of the anchors of the chemical business. In August of 2007, I ended my tenure with Multi-Chem. I was considering a District manager position with BJ Chemicals when a mentor and customer approached me and asked what I would do. I told him my options, and he said these words to me, "I've watched you work your ass off for all these companies the last 13 years, and the only advice I can give you is that if you work half as hard for yourself as you have these companies, you will do just fine. And that is where Phoenix Chemical Technologies was born. 

Phoenix had a good start. We did very well in South Texas, and even after the NatGas prices fell, we had a solid customer base that believed in and saw the benefit of our chemical program. The difference between what I learned at Coastal Chemical and what I saw Multi-Chem not doing paid off in my program. Some metrics need to be documented for the operator and just as significantly for the chemical provider so that they can be proactive in controlling costs and maximizing performance and ROI for their customer. In addition to that, being located in DeWitt County and having relationships with landowners allowed me access to the new Eagle Ford wells being drilled. I took advantage of that and quickly realized that the issues looming were with Paraffin. I immediately began working with formulations and paraffin inhibitors to combat that problem. I formulated three proprietary blends that all worked best between 250 ppm and 750 ppm treatment rates. This was crucial because most of my competitors, then and now, cannot get below 1500 ppm and have an effective program. Between 2007 and 2014, I grew Phoenix to a $50 MILLION valuation. 

However, in 2015, we all know what happened. In February 2015, Phoenix Chemical Technologies was still treating 1.5 million barrels of oil equivalent per month for an average BOE of $0.71/bbl. Murphy Oil commissioned a study by MAXIM Oil that tagged their BOE between $4-$7/bbl. I had access to that report and felt confident that as oil prices slid, we (Phoenix Chemical) would be tapped to come in with a chemical to treat their problems at a more reasonable BOE and grow our customer base while the others struggled. I was feeling cocky and confident that this time the Hastings Group wouldn't lowball an offer for the company at one-fifth the actual value. At that time, our largest customer was Comstock; we were over 1 million BOE with them alone at $0.70/bbl. They had a shake-up, and Jay Callarman took over. The first thing that he did was fire Phoenix and replace us with Multi-Chem and Nalco-Champion. I had access to production reports and chemical expenditures until Trinity acquired those assets. (you have to love the failings of corporations.)Those reports showed a decrease of production by >30% and a chemical expenditure jump to $2.7 million/month. This was the beginning of the end, that was my first introduction to true financial stupidity and from there it spiraled as procurement started making decisions that the field personnel could no longer make. That is still happening today, for the life of me when are these corporations going to start to evaluate true cost of ownership? The cost of a chemical program is not in the price per gallon but in performance. If I sell a $25/gallon chemical and you only use 2 gallons your total cost is $50, but if you purchase $15/gallon and use 2.5x more, your daily usage is $75, not to mention the additional costs associated with a chemical not performing as well as the premium product, such as hot oil costs, production declines, pipeline capacity, increased pressures, and those operating costs. A whole chain of issues now impacts the operator because procurement doesn't perform a cost-benefit analysis correctly, and the chemical companies no longer provide the proper reporting to back up their programs. 

So, enter Mako Chemicals. It was short-lived because it was a partnership with my then-fiance, and I chose to exit the service side of the business to focus on my proprietary chemistry and establish myself and Xtreme Performance Chemicals as a manufacturer and technical support organization. 

Xtreme Performance Chemicals - xHRC platform. The xHRC platform is a multi-modal chemistry designed for multiple oil and gas recovery applications. It is the backbone of Xtreme Performance Chemicals. I have dedicated fourteen years to research and development and have some outstanding success stories to back it up. Unfortunately, when I collaborated with Cole Chemical, Donna Cole could leverage her relationship with BP to present it to their team, and they immediately made arrangements to have Donna present the data to Baker and Nalco. They told her, and I quote, "We are not interested because it would bastardize 3-4 of our revenue streams." I am not interested in bastardizing anything; I am just interested in getting a better product to market in the hands of conscientious operators focused on maximizing oil and gas recovery and increasing their ROI. Why would it not make sense to apply every chemistry or technology that improves? Maybe, in some cases, it would double recovery from existing wells. 

So, over the past several years, I have been introduced to entrepreneurs focusing on EOR technology. Although they have proprietary technology, I focus on how we can collaborate and bring new technology to the market and work with individuals and groups that have key specialties and unique skill sets that can identify behind pipe pay that these technologies can be used to maximize recovery and lower operating costs to turn liabilities into assets. One of my key focuses is to get the xHRC platform into fracs as a flowback aid and then identify the water treatment process. After all, the chemistry was originally developed for the water well industry. Over the years, I have shied away from that, especially after I have had water well drillers tell me that they would not utilize this chemistry because they are in the drilling business, not the water well repair business.
